content:
But trillion-dollar deficits and a new core of spending hawks in the House and Senate are beginning to change that . Tax breaks once routinely extended — for business research and development , or wind energy , for instance — are languishing . Spending cuts proposed by the executive branch and rejected by legislators protecting their turf are getting a second look .
“ Everybody ’ s got to take a hit , ” said Alan K. Simpson , a former Republican senator from Wyoming . As a co-chairman of President Obama ’ s deficit reduction commission in 2010 , he suggested targeting the mine fund , which was set up to clear out and fill abandoned coal mines , largely with a small fee on coal .
The vast majority of programs in the $ 127 billion transportation legislation will be financed with existing federal taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel . But for some things , lawmakers had to turn elsewhere — and elsewhere hurts .
The transportation bill includes increases in premiums for companies insured by the federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation ; higher premiums for federal flood insurance ; a cap on payments from the abandoned mines fund that will affect only one state , Wyoming ; and a limit on the length of time a student can receive subsidized loans . All of those proposals reflect measures included in President Obama ’ s budget this winter . Most had been declared dead on arrival .
“ Part of that is just the enormity of the deficits and the public ’ s interest on the subject , ” said Robert Bixby , executive director of the Concord Coalition , a fiscal watchdog group . “ It ’ s hard to come forward with anything that ’ s not quote-unquote paid for . ”
Congress has yet to come up with anything that would truly take a dent out of the deficit , because Republicans refuse to raise taxes and Democrats are protecting Medicare and Social Security . Just taxing all compensation for hedge fund and private equity managers as income , not capital gains , would raise $ 3 billion a year , dwarfing the savings secured from the mine fund .
“ Focusing on tiny little things to address tiny little targets is a lot less effective than addressing the larger picture , ” said Richard Kogan , a fiscal expert at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities .

But tiny little things can smart , too . One provision will tax tobacco shops as manufacturers if they allow shoppers to roll their own cigarettes on in-house machinery . Under existing rules , smokers who use shops ’ machines can escape state and federal cigarette taxes . The main company that makes the equipment , RYO Machine of Girard , Ohio , has battled such tax changes in half the states in the country , and won . Just last week , a similar measure pushed by Gov . Andrew Cuomo of New York died in the State Senate .
But Congress decided it needed an estimated $ 94 million over 10 years to help finance a rural education program in the transportation bill . Bea Gonzalez , a spokeswoman for RYO Machine , says that the money will not materialize because most shops will just end the service . And RYO Machine will suffer the consequences .
President George W. Bush ’ s budget office took aim in 2006 at a federal program called “ ocean freight differential ” that reimburses agencies for the cost of shipping foreign food aid aboard United States-flagged ships instead of on cheaper , foreign-flagged vessels . Nothing came of that until now . The transportation bill cuts back the percentage of aid mandated to be shipped under the program , saving $ 108 million a year .
For symbolism , the cut involving the abandoned mine fund may be the most important . As far back as 2001 , President Bush proposed cuts to the program . In 2006 , Wyoming ’ s Republican Congressional delegation reworked the program to protect it , reclassifying it as “ mandatory ” — not subject to Congress ’ s annual spending bills . President Obama made it a centerpiece for his efforts to cut what he called wasteful programs .
Lawmakers in Wyoming , by far the largest recipient of money from the fund , said the state ’ s coal industry paid into it with the understanding that the money would come back and could be used however the Legislature deemed necessary . For instance , tens of millions has gone to the University of Wyoming for laboratory facilities and a new school of energy resources . The fund was to be tapped for this year ’ s renovation of the university ’ s basketball arena in Laramie , but an outcry forced the legislature to look for money elsewhere .
It wasn ’ t just Wyoming lawmakers who balked at the cut . Senator Max Baucus of Montana , the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee , whose state also is a beneficiary , opposed the president ’ s plan to terminate the fund altogether , which would have saved $ 1.5 billion . Instead , Mr. Baucus proposed capping state payments at $ 15 million a year . Wyoming , which gets about 80 percent of the money , happens to be the only state that gets more than $ 15 million a year .
Without the money , a University of Wyoming clean coal research effort is in jeopardy . And the university will have to struggle to finance a planned $ 100 million renovation of its College of Engineering and Applied Science , said Chad Baldwin , a university spokesman .
“ This would be a big loss for us , ” he said .
